§ 50.01 DEPARTMENT OF WATER WORKS ESTABLISHED.
   Pursuant to the provisions of an Act of the State General Assembly entitled,
“An Act authorizing cities and towns owning and operating water works to create
a Department of Water Works, establishing a water district and the boundaries
thereof, providing for a building extension and additions to such Water Works
and for the operation, maintenance and management thereof, authorizing the
issuance and sales of bonds payable solely from revenue of such Water Works,
matters connected therewith,” a Department of Water Works in the city is hereby
created, which Department of Water Works shall be subject to the provisions of
the Act.
(I.C. 8-1.5-4) (‘89 Code, § 104.01) (Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.02 BOARD OF DIRECTORS.
   (A)   The city utilities shall be under the exclusive management and control
of a Board of Directors, to be known and designated as the City Utilities
Board. The City Utilities Board shall consist of five members, each of whom
shall be a resident of the area serviced by the city utilities.
   (B)   The directors each shall be appointed by the Mayor. The term of
Director is four years. There are no term limits. Not more than three of the
directors shall be affiliated with the same political party. Each director’s
term shall begin on July 1.
   (C)   Any vacancy occurring in the Board of Directors shall be filled for
the unexpired term by the Mayor.
   (D)   Each of the directors elected shall immediately qualify for and take
office as prescribed, and shall continue to serve as director and perform his
or her duties as provided by law during the term for which he or she was
appointed.
(‘89 Code, § 104.02)
   (E)   Each qualified director shall receive as full compensation for his or
her service the sum of $200 per month. This sum shall be compensation for
attendance at any and all regular and/or special meetings, and for any and all
other services rendered to the City Department of Water Works.
(‘89 Code, § 104.03)
   (F)   The amount of the bond for each officer and member of the Board of
Directors appointed to manage and control the Department of Water Works shall
be $10,000.
(‘89 Code, § 104.04)
   (G)   Upon the election of the members of the Board of Water Works Directors
and their qualification as required by law, they shall function as the Board of
Directors of the Department of Water Works and shall have and possess all of
the rights, powers, duties and liabilities that are set forth or prescribed by
statute.
      (1)   The Board of Directors shall adopt and maintain the policies, rules
and regulations of the Department and may bill its customers charges incidental
to its operations and in accordance with its rules and regulations.
      (2)   The Board of Directors will make recommendations to the City
Council on rates and fees. The City Council shall have the responsibility to
set the rates and fees for the Department.
(‘89 Code, § 104.05)
   (H)   All liabilities incurred by the city in the ownership and operation of
the Water Works system, including all necessary expenses incurred by the city
in creation of the Department of Water Works and in effecting the transfer of
the Water Works to the Board of Directors of the Water Department shall be
assumed by the directors to pay and discharge in accordance with the provisions
of the law. Payment and discharge of the liabilities may be made by the Board
of Directors out of cash or proceeds of accounts receivable transferred by the
Board of Public Works of the city or out of the operation and maintenance of
the Depreciation Fund.
   (I)   The Board of Public Works shall relinquish and transfer to the Board
of Water Works Directors control of all lands, personal properties and duties,
subject to any contracts now in force, which have been in any way a part of or
connected with the Water Works system of the city. It shall be the duty of the
Board of Water Works Directors to receive the same as prescribed by law.
(‘89 Code, § 104.06) (Am. Ord. passed - -01; Am. Ord. 30-2011, passed 11-14-11)
§ 50.03 DESTRUCTION OF WATER WORKS PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
   No person shall, without written authority from the General Manager of Water
Works, change, modify, break or in any way or manner interfere with or injure,
deface or remove any part or parcel of the Water Works or place or deposit any
earth or other material in any public or private hydrant or shut off valve
boxes, or in any way interfere with the use of any part or attachment connected
with the Water Works. Tampering, modifying or destroying of meters is
prohibited.
(‘89 Code, § 104.07) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 50.04 TAMPERING WITH FIRE HYDRANTS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person, except members of the fire department in case of a fire or
during a regular test or trial of the Fire Department, shall, without the
written authority of the General Manager of Water Works, open any fire hydrant
or remove any cap or caps from the same.
   (B)   No person shall be authorized to use a fire hydrant without first
receiving proper training from a person authorized by the Department of Water
Works to conduct the training.
(‘89 Code, § 104.08) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 50.05 TAMPERING WITH PIPES OR MAINS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall, without the written permission and authority of the General
Manager of Water Works, tap any main or pipe forming any part of the Water
Works owned by the city, do any work in connection with the introduction of
water into any premises, or alter, extend, change or modify any water pipe or
fixture already installed in any premises, or make or cut off connections in
any way whatever with or from the mains or service pipes of the Department of
Water Works.
(‘89 Code, § 104.09) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 50.06 UNAUTHORIZED USE OF WATER PROHIBITED.
   No person shall take or use water from the Water Works for domestic or other
purposes without having previously contracted for the same in compliance with
the rules and regulations of the Water Works Department.
(‘89 Code, § 104.10) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 50.07 EXTENSION OF WATER SERVICES.
   (A)   It shall be lawful but not obligatory for the Department of Water
Works to permit and to furnish water to properties outside the corporate
boundaries of the city, which properties are within a distance of five miles
from the current corporate boundaries of the city upon terms and conditions
that are acceptable to the Department.
   (B)   As a condition to furnishing the municipal services or either of them,
the property owners shall sign a waiver and an agreement binding upon
themselves, their heirs, assigns and grantees, agreeing therein to come into
the corporate boundaries of the city and waiving their rights to object to
annexation when and if the city decides by ordinance that the land so affected
by the terms of the ordinance should be annexed to the city.
(‘89 Code, § 104.11)
   (C)   All extensions of city water shall be paid for at the expense of the
benefited properties as is now provided for by law, except as authorized by
Board of Directors resolution. There shall in no way be cast upon the civil
city any additional obligations to construct water services other than those
provided by law.
(‘89 Code, § 104.12) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.08 RATE SCHEDULE OUTSIDE OF CITY.
   Any property owner who resides outside of the city and receives water
services as provided in this chapter shall pay the rate charged to a property
owner within the corporate boundaries of the city and in accord with the
existing rate schedule then in effect.
(‘89 Code, § 104.14) (Am. Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.09 CROSS CONNECTIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      CROSS CONNECTION. Any physical arrangement, including cross connection
control devices or backflow prevention devices not in working order, whereby
the public water supply distribution  system is directly connected, either
continuously or intermittently, with any secondary source of water supply,
sewer, drain, conduit, pool, piping, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture or
other device which contains, or may contain, and is capable of imparting to the
public water supply, contaminants, contaminated water, sewage, storm water or
other waste of liquid of unknown or unsafe quality.
   (B)   Pursuant to the provisions of 327 IAC 8-10-1, cross connections
between potable water systems and other systems or equipment containing water
or other substances are prohibited, except when and where approved by the
Department of Water Works, suitable protective devices such as appropriate back
flow prevention devices or equal are installed, tested and maintained to ensure
proper operation on a continuing basis. It shall be the responsibility of each
water supply user and/or other property owner to meet these requirements at the
user’s and/or property owner’s expense.
   (C)   In order to protect the public water system from contamination due to
contaminants through the water service connection into the public water system,
a program of regulation, testing and inspection shall be adopted by the
Department of Water Works.
   (D)   The plumbing in every building or premises served by the Department of
Water Works shall be inspected by a qualified plumber who is an IDEM certified
cross connection inspector and the plumber/inspector shall provide a written
report of the inspection as required by the Department of Water Works.
   (E)   The General Manager or his or her designated agent shall have the
right-of-entry into every building or premises served by the Department of
Water Works during reasonable hours for the purpose of making inspection of
plumbing systems connected to the public water supply. Refusal to allow
inspection of a building or premises is cause for requiring the installation of
a maximum hazard backflow prevention device at the owner’s expense, or
discontinuation of public water supply service.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.10 RESALE OF WATER.
   No water may be resold or furnished by the customer to any other building or
premises, except in case of emergency and on approval of the General Manager.
(Ord. passed - -01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 50.11 WELLHEAD PROTECTION PLAN (WHPP).
   The Department of Water Works shall develop and maintain a WHPP plan to
provide drinking water source protection and as required pursuant to 327 IAC 8-
4.1.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.12 RIGHT-OF-ENTRY BY DEPARTMENT OF WATER WORKS EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Authorized employees of the Department of Water Works shall have the
right-of-entry to any building or premises for the purpose of reading,
inspecting and maintaining water meters and automatic meter reading devices or
for the purpose of making inspections in order to maintain the public water
supply system in good condition and to provide for the protection of the public
water supply system.
   (B)   Where inspections are not of an immediate or urgent nature, employees
of the Department of Water Works shall arrange for appointments mutually
convenient to the owners or occupants of the building or premises and any
authorized employees.
   (C)   Any person refusing to permit any authorized employee of the
Department of Water Works access to the building or premises shall be in
violation of this chapter and subject to suspension of water services until
access is received.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.13 CONNECTION REQUIRED.
   It shall be the duty of the owner of any occupied building, dwelling or
premises abutting on the Department of Water Works main to cause the structure
to be connected with the main within six months from the date that the water
main becomes available for use to the structure.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.14 WATER CONSERVATION PLAN.
   During times of drought, it may be necessary to require conservation of
public water sources. The Department of Water Works shall have a plan to
conserve water at times that the public water supply is deemed by the
Department of Water Works to be substantially affected by drought conditions.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.15 USE OF PRIVATE WELLS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   No private water wells shall be constructed, reconstructed or
reconditioned within the corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to the repair or replacement of pumping
equipment in existing wells.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to properties that do not have a public
water main within 300 feet of the closest edge of the property.
   (D)   It is deemed unlawful and in violation of this chapter to connect a
private well to a system that is connected to the public water supply.
Connection of this type is considered a cross connection.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.16 SEALING OF WELLS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Upon connection to the public water supply, any wells serving the
property shall be abandoned and sealed in accordance with applicable state
regulations.
   (B)   Any well that is abandoned for a period of one year must be sealed in
accordance with applicable state regulations.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.17 LIABILITY AND OWNERSHIP OF MAINS, SERVICES AND FIXTURES.
   (A)   The Department of Water Works shall maintain specifications and
standards for all mains, connection services and valves within the public water
supply system. Plumbing and fixtures shall be regulated by the city building
bodes, cross connection regulations and appropriate state codes. The Department
of Water Works owns and operates all water mains and services between and
including the main and curb box shut-off valve. In addition, the Department of
Water Works shall own the water meter and meter reading devices installed
within the building, dwelling or premises.
   (B)   The property owner owns and has liability for the water connection
service from, and excluding, the curb box shut-off valve to the building or
structure.
   (C)   The Department of Water Works shall not be liable for any damages
caused by a leak or break in any private part of the water connection service.
The costs associated with the repair and/or replacement of any portion of the
private part of the water connection service shall be paid by the property
owner, including any additional water usage resulting from the occurrence.
   (D)   The Department of Water Works shall not be responsible for any damage
to buildings, trees or other obstructions within Department of Water Works
easements and/or public rights-of-way that may result from work being performed
in the easements and/or public rights-of-way by the Department of Water Works.
   (E)   If a leak develops in the water service while a party is performing
work on a water service, it shall be the responsibility of the person causing
the leak to repair the item at his or her expense in a timely manner.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.18 INSTALLATION OF SEWERS IN CLOSE PROXIMITY OF EXISTING WATER MAINS.
   (A)   All sanitary and storm sewer lines shall be laid to provide a minimum
horizontal distance of ten feet and, in case of a crossing, a vertical distance
18 inches from any existing or proposed water main. The distance shall be
measured from the outside edge of the water main to the outside edge of the
sewer. In the case of a crossing, the joints of the sewer shall be located as
far from the joint of the water main as possible. Special structural support
for the water main and sewer may be required by the Department.
   (B)   In cases where it is not practical to maintain the required horizontal
and vertical minimum distances, the Department must specifically approve any
variance from the minimum distance requirements. Where these distances cannot
be met, the sewers shall, at a minimum, be constructed of water main type and
grade or equivalent, and shall be pressure tested to ensure water tightness.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.19 ADDITION OF STATUTORY AUTHORITY.
   Upon acceptance and approval of the foregoing provisions by the City
Council, and by virtue of the powers given to the Department of Water Works
herein, the City Council further adopts by reference and grants to the
Department of Water Works all powers, duties and rights set forth in I.C. 8-
1.5-4, as amended, together with all other rules and regulations governing the
same.
(Ord. passed - -01)
§ 50.20 PAYMENT IN LIEU OF TAXES FOR OUTSIDE TERRITORY CUSTOMERS.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      EQUIVALENT DWELLING UNIT ("EDU"). The equivalent of a single-family
residential dwelling unit calculated as follows:
         Annual flow for the most recent 12 month period (in gallons)    xxx
         Divided by days of the year                ÷365   =   xx
         Daily Flow                         xx
         Divided by single family residential daily flow          ÷310   =   x
         EDUs                           x
      OUTSIDE TERRITORY CUSTOMERS. Those properties and premises that are
connected to and served by the Damon Run System but are located outside of its
service territory. The term includes all properties and premises that are
currently connected to the system or that are connected in the future.
   (B)   Payment in lieu of taxes (PILOT). There is established a monthly PILOT
applicable to the outside territory customers in the amount as presented on
Exhibit A of Ord. 26-2019 to be adjusted annually for the "true-up" defined
below. The number of EDUs applicable to each outside territory customer shall
be determined according to the terms of such customer's service agreement as
defined above. The amount of the PILOT shall be "trued-up" or adjusted each
year to ensure that the outside territory customers are paying an amount
consistent with the service agreements and the ongoing needs of Damon Run.
   (C)   Existing rates and charges. This section is only intended to establish
PILOTs for Damon Run's outside territory customers. Unless specifically amended
by this section, all other city water rates, charges, and provisions related
thereto shall remain in full force and effect.
   (D)   Classification of rates and charges. The PILOTs set forth herein will
not be imposed based on whether the customer in question is inside or outside
the city limits, but rather will be based on whether the customer will be
served by the distinct and separate Damon Run water facilities. Other than the
outside territory customers, the city and VCU do not collect PILOTs from any
other customers.
(Ord. 26-2019, passed 10-28-19)
