GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 72.01 METHOD OF PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than
parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic
movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the
curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this code.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the above paragraph, no person shall stand or park a
vehicle on the left hand side of a one-way street other than parallel with the
edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with
the left-hand wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the curb or edge of the
roadway.
   (C)   Upon those streets which have been signed or marked by the Board of
Public Works and Safety for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a
vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by
the signs or markings.
(‘89 Code, § 62.01)
§ 72.02 STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN DESIGNATED AREAS.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to
avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the direction of
a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places or
because of any of the following circumstances:
      (1)   On a sidewalk;
      (2)   In front of a public or private driveway;
      (3)   Within an intersection;
      (4)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;
      (5)   On a crosswalk;
      (6)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection;
      (7)   Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign
or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway;
      (8)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.
      (9)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction, when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
      (10)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb or a street;
      (11)   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel;
      (12)   At any place where official signs, and or (temporary police order
or temporary no parking signs) prohibit stopping, standing or parking;
      (13)   At any location where the curb or roadway is painted yellow to
depict a no parking zone; and
      (14)   In any location including an authorized parking space where the
parking shall obstruct the visibility for any oncoming traffic from any
direction resulting in a hazardous situation for other drivers, a vehicle will
be in violation of this code.
   (B)   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his or her control
into a prohibited area or away from a curb a distance that is unlawful.
(‘89 Code, § 62.02) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.03 ALLEY PARKING RESTRICTED.
   No person shall park a vehicle within any alley, except for the purpose of
loading or unloading freight, in a manner or under conditions so as to leave
available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement
of vehicular traffic. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an
alley in a position so as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting
property.
(‘89 Code, § 62.03)
§ 72.04 PARKING AFTER SNOWFALL PROHIBITED.
   No person, except physicians on emergency calls, shall park a vehicle on any
street when there is two or more inches of snow thereon.
(‘89 Code, § 62.04)
§ 72.05 PARKING FOR SALE OR REPAIR PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principle purpose
of:
   (A)   Displaying the vehicle for sale; or
   (B)   Washing, greasing or repairing the vehicle, except repairs
necessitated by an emergency.
(‘89 Code, § 62.05)
§ 72.06 PARKING IN CONGESTED LOCATIONS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley,
in a manner or in a condition so as to leave available less than ten feet of
the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic.
   (B)   When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon any narrow
streets, or at hazardous or congested locations, or on one-way streets, all as
authorized by this code, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon any
street in violation of any sign of these types.
(‘89 Code, § 62.06)
§ 72.07 NO PARKING ZONES.
   (A)   Parking on certain streets or parts of streets in the city shall be
prohibited when, in the opinion of the City Board of Public Works and Safety,
the prohibition provides for the smoother flow of traffic, removal of traffic
congestion or when the prohibition is in the best interests of the city.
   (B)   A violation of this section shall occur when a vehicle is parked upon
a street or part of a street designated as a no parking zone.
(‘89 Code, § 62.07)
§ 72.08 TWO-HOUR AND THREE-HOUR PARKING ZONES.
   (A)   In any area designated as a two-hour or three-hour parking zone or
parking lot and when signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall
stop, stand or park a vehicle for a period of time longer than two hours or
three hours as designated between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., except
Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall determine the areas of the
city that shall be designated as two-hour parking zones, and shall provide for
signs indicating this designation, or may provide for notice to be placed on
parking meters if the same are deemed necessary.
   (C)   The purpose of this section is to provide notice to the user of a
parking space as to the parking requirements therefore.
(‘89 Code, § 62.08) (Am. Ord. passed - - ; Am. Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.09 RESTRICTED PARKING AREAS.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety may limit the time of parking at
any parking space within the city of a period of less than two hours when the
restriction is deemed to be in the best interest of the city or provides for
the smoother flow of traffic or for the removal of traffic congestion.
   (B)   The restricted parking areas shall be designated by sign or may
provide for notice to be placed on parking meters if the notice is deemed
necessary.
(‘89 Code, § 62.09)
§ 72.10 TOWING OF VEHICLES.
   When the city Police Department deems necessary, and vehicle may be moved or
impounded that is in violation as stated in this chapter. Whenever possible an
attempt shall be made to contact the last registered owner of the vehicle prior
to the removal of that vehicle. The city Police Department will contact a duty
wrecker that is on call for the city at the time of the occurrence. The
property owner of the illegally parked vehicle will be responsible for any
towing charges and or storage incurred by the violation.
(‘89 Code, § 62.11)
§ 72.11 AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND VEHICLES.
   (A)   The Police Department is hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from a
street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a
garage designated or maintained by the Police Department or otherwise
maintained by the city in the following circumstances:
      (1)   When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct or
causeway, or in any tube or tunnel where the vehicle constitutes an obstruction
to traffic.
      (2)   When a vehicle upon a highway is so disabled as to constitute an
obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are
by reasons of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable
to provide for its custody or removal.
      (3)   When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or is parked
illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal
movement of traffic.
      (4)   A vehicle may be moved or impounded if found to be in violation of
this chapter.
   (B)   Whenever a police officer removes a vehicle from a street and knows or
is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and
address of the owner, the officer shall, within a reasonable time, notify the
owner of the removal and reasons therefore, and of the place where the vehicle
is located. In the event the vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of
the notice shall be given to the garage proprietor.
   (C)   If the police officer does not know and is not able to ascertain the
name of the owner or for any other reason is unable to notify the owner as
provided, and the vehicle is not returned to the owner, the officer shall send
a written report by mail to the State Department whose duty it is to register
motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of the notice with the proprietor of the
garage, if any where the vehicle is stored. The notice shall include a complete
description of the vehicle, the date, time, and place from which removed, the
reasons for the removal, and the name of the place or garage where the vehicle
is stored.
(‘89 Code, § 60.08)
§ 72.12 DOWNTOWN PARKING RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, certain terms or words used herein
shall be given the following meanings:
      VEHICLE. Any device in, upon, or by which a person or property is, or may
be, transported or drawn upon a street or highway as defined in I.C. 9-13-2-
196.
   (B)   The Council declares the parking of vehicles, as defined by this
section, in certain areas and at certain times within the city to be a public
nuisance and prohibited activity.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity
to park in or to permit to remain stationary any vehicle in the following
prohibited areas at the following times:
      (1)   No vehicle shall be parked along Lincolnway (both sides of the
street) from Napoleon Street to Morgan Boulevard on Mondays from 11:00 p.m.
Sunday to 5:00 a.m. Monday;
      (2)   No vehicle shall be parked along Michigan Avenue from Indiana
Avenue to Jefferson Street on Tuesdays from 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m.;
      (3)   No vehicle shall be parked along Franklin Street from Indiana
Avenue to Jefferson Street on Tuesdays from 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m.;
      (4)   No vehicle shall be parked along Washington Street from Indiana
Avenue to Jefferson Street on Tuesdays from 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m.;
      (5)   No vehicle shall be parked along Lafayette Street from Indiana
Avenue to Jefferson Street Tuesdays from 1:00 a.m to 5:00 a.m.; and
      (6)   No vehicle shall be parked along either side of Napoleon Street
from Indiana Avenue to Jefferson Street on Tuesdays from 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m.
   (D)   Any vehicle found to be in violation of this section or any other
ordinance regulating parking is subject to being removed without notice to the
vehicle’s owner.
   (E)   Upon observing any vehicle in violation of this section or any other
ordinance regulating parking, the Police Department shall contact the towing
service employed by the city and have said vehicle removed.
   (F)   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prevent the Department
of Public Works from having a vehicle found in violation of this section or any
other ordinance regulating parking removed by a towing service.
   (G)   The owner of any vehicle found to be in violation of this section
shall be solely responsible and liable for all costs incidental to the removal,
storage or disposition of said vehicle.
   (H)   The city, its agents, representatives and employees shall not be
liable for the loss or damage to any vehicle occurring during the removal,
storage or disposition of said vehicle pursuant to this section.
   (I)   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit the operation
and/or parking of any vehicle owned or operated by the city or its various
departments for legitimate governmental purposes.
   (J)   Violation of this section or any other ordinance regulating parking
within the city shall also be punishable by a citation. In addition, the city
may seek injunctive relief against any and all persons, firms, corporations or
other entities who violate the provisions of this section. All fines can be
paid at the City Hall. All fines paid to the city as a result of a violation of
this section shall be deposited into the Parking Meter Fund.
(Ord. 13-2008, passed 5-12-08)
§ 72.13 CITY LOT.
   It shall be unlawful to park any kind of vehicle in a city owned or operated
parking lot from 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. prevailing time without a valid city-
issued permit. Any vehicle parked in a parking lot during this time may be
towed away and the owner or person exerting control over the vehicle will be
subject to removal costs. This section shall be applicable at all times and is
not restricted to snow emergencies only. The city reserves the right to post
any city owned or operated lot closed with 24 hours notice or at any time in
the event of an emergency.
(Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
PARKING METERS AND PERMITS
§ 72.20 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MECHANICAL PARKING TIME INDICATOR or PARKING METER. A device which indicates
thereon: the length of time during which a vehicle may be parked in a
particular place which shall have as a part thereof a receptacle or chamber for
receiving and storing coins of the United States money, or a slot or place in
which coins or other acceptable forms of payment may be deposited; a timing
mechanism to indicate the passage of an interval of time during which parking
is permissible; which shall display an appropriate signal when the aforesaid
interval of time shall have elapsed; also brief instructions as to its
operation.
(‘89 Code, § 63.01) (Am. Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.21 LENGTH OF PARKING TIME.
   The length of allowable parking time at metered spaces within the city shall
be designated on the meterhead at the space or on signs located near each space
or in each parking lot. The length of time for any individual meter or any
individual parking space on the street or in any municipally owned lot may be
changed by the official action of the Board of Public Works and Safety at their
discretion.
(‘89 Code, § 63.03) (Am. Ord. 65, passed 12-16-96; Am. Ord. passed - - ; Am.
Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.22 INSTALLATION AND OPERATION OF METERS.
   (A)   Parking meters may be installed in each parking meter zone, street, or
municipally owned or operated parking lot as may be determined from time to
time by the Board of Public Works and Safety and shall be erected upon the curb
or street immediately adjacent to an individual parking space.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall have lines or approximate
markings painted upon the curb of the street adjacent to each parking meter
outlining and designating the parking space for which the meter is to be used,
and each vehicle parked adjacent to any parking meter shall be parked within
the lines or markings.
   (C)   Each meter shall indicate by a proper legend the legal parking time
permitted by the insertion of any coin or coins or other acceptable forms of
payment, and when operated shall indicate by proper signal the duration of the
period of legal parking during the immediate period of operation, and on the
expiration of the period shall immediately indicate illegal or overtime
parking. If the meter dispenses a ticket, receipt or other indication of
allowable duration of parking, it shall be displayed in the manner indicated on
the legend on or near the meter.
(‘89 Code, § 63.04) (Am. Ord. passed - - ; Am. Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.23 PARKING METER SPACES.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works shall have lines or appropriate markings
painted upon the curb or street adjacent to each parking meter outlining and
designating the parking meter zone or space for which the meter is to be used,
and each vehicle parked adjacent to any parking meter shall be parked within
these lines or markings.
   (B)   No person shall park any vehicle across or without the lines or
markings, or park a vehicle in a position that it shall not be entirely within
the space designated by the lines or marks.
(‘89 Code, § 63.05) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.24 LOADING ZONES.
   The Board of Public Works may provide, by appropriate markings or lines,
loading zones on streets or parts thereof which may be used by commercial
trucks or delivery trucks for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise
or materials without the erection of parking meters thereon or the requirement
of the deposit of any coin or coins for the purpose only of loading and
unloading. No vehicle shall occupy a loading zone for a period in excess of 30
minutes.
(‘89 Code, § 63.06) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.25 PAYMENT OF METER REQUIRED.
   Whenever a vehicle is parked in an individual parking space where a parking
meter has been installed, the person parking the vehicle shall deposit lawful
money of the United States in the amount designated on the meter for payment
for parking. Parking at all meters in the city shall be at the rate established
for that location by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(‘89 Code, § 63.08) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.26 SCHEDULE OF CHARGES.
   (A)   Upon deposit of the coin or coins required, which would thus place the
parking meter in operation, the parking space may be lawfully occupied by a
vehicle for the length of time as determined and set out on the meterhead.
   (B)   Charges for the various meters located throughout the city may be set
from time to time by the action of the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(‘89 Code, § 63.09)
§ 72.27 HOURS FOR USE OF METERS.
   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to vehicles parking or
standing in a parking space adjacent to a parking meter between the hours of 6:
00 p.m. in the evening until 8:00 a.m. the following morning of each weekday
except Friday, when the provisions shall not apply between the hours of 9:00
p.m. Friday evening until 8:00 a.m. Saturday morning. The provisions of this
subchapter shall not apply on Sundays or legal holidays.
(‘89 Code, § 63.10) (Am. Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.28 UNLAWFUL PARKING PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall cause or permit any vehicle owned or operated by him
or her to be upon any street in any parking meter zone in any space adjacent to
which a parking meter is installed at any time during which the meter is
showing a signal indicating illegal or overtime parking.
(‘89 Code, § 63.11) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
   (B)   No person shall cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered
in the name of, or operated by the person to be parked overtime or beyond the
period of legal parking time established for any parking meter zone described
in this subchapter.
(‘89 Code, § 63.12)
§ 72.29 PRESUMPTION THAT OWNER PARKED CAR.
   In any prosecution charging a violation of any section of this subchapter,
proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in
violation of any law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant
named in the complaint was at the time of the parking registered owner of the
vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the
registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked or placed the vehicle
at the point where, and for the time during which, the violation occurred.
(‘89 Code, § 63.13) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.30 DEPOSITS OF SLUGS; TAMPERING WITH METERS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any meter a slug,
device or metallic substance, or any other substitute for coin of the United
States.
(‘89 Code, § 63.14)
   (B)   No person shall deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break,
destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter.
(‘89 Code, § 63.15)
§ 72.31 DUTY OF POLICE DEPARTMENT TO REPORT VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of Police Department, through the use of police
officers or other designated agents of the Department, to report any violations
of this chapter to the Chief of Police. The following information shall be
reported:
      (1)   The number of each parking meter which indicated that the vehicle
occupying the parking space adjacent to the parking meter is or has been parked
in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   The state license of the vehicle;
      (3)   The time at which the violation occurred; and
      (4)   Any other facts necessary to a thorough understanding of the
circumstances attending the violation.
   (B)   Each police officer or designated agent of the Department shall also
attach to the vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that the
vehicle has been parked in violation of this chapter, and instructing the owner
or operator to report at the police station in regard to the violation. The
notice shall show the time of the violation.
   (C)   Furthermore, the Chief, Deputy Chief and Division Chief of the Fire
Department, in addition to police officers, have the right and authority to
issue and enforce, by issuing citations, violations of §§
72.02(A)(4) and
72.02(A)(12) on all public and private schools and hospital properties in order
to protect the safety, health and welfare of the residents of the city and
their guests.
(‘89 Code, § 63.16) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.32 METER COIN COLLECTORS.
   The Mayor shall designate some member or members of the Police Department to
collect the coins deposited in parking meters. From parking meters equipped
with sealed coin chambers or compartments, the collector shall remove the
chamber and deliver it with seal unbroken to the Clerk-Treasurer. From parking
meters not equipped with sealed coin chambers or compartments, the collector
shall remove the coins from the coin box of each meter so as to permit the
coins to fall unobstructed into the cart, and deliver the same to the Clerk-
Treasurer. The Clerk-Treasurer shall count the coins so delivered and deposit
the same to the credit of the city.
(‘89 Code, § 63.18)
§ 72.33 PARKING LAW CONFLICTS.
   The provisions of this subchapter shall not be construed as modifying or
changing to any extent whatsoever the traffic and parking laws set forth in
other portions of this code which restrict or prohibit parking.
(‘89 Code, § 63.20)
§ 72.34 OFF-STREET METER PERMITS.
   (A)   It shall be lawful to park a suitable motor vehicle in any available
designated parking space in any off-street parking facility in the city for any
length of time without depositing any coin or other acceptable forms of payment
in the parking meter controlling the space when the vehicle shall have properly
affixed an off-street parking permit decal for the current calendar year.
(Am. Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
   (B)   The privilege created by this section shall be on a first come, first
served basis, and shall not guarantee the holder of the permit of the
availability of a parking space.
(‘89 Code, § 63.21)
   (C)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall have prepared a suitable number of decals,
approximately two by two and one-half inches in size, to be known and
designated as an “off-street parking permit.” The decal shall designate the
calendar year for which it is to be issued for use, and from year to year shall
be of a distinctive color clearly contrasting the color of the previous year.
The decal shall bear the words “This permit authorizes the owner or operator of
the vehicle to which it is properly affixed to park the vehicle in any
available designated space in any off-street parking facility of the city
during the year for which it is issued, without placing any coin in the parking
meter controlling the space. This permit is not valid or effected in any on-
street metered or restricted parking space.” The decals shall be numbered
consecutively, beginning with number one, for each year.
(‘89 Code, § 63.22)
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall procure a consecutively numbered receipt
book with numbers corresponding to the permit numbers, with space in which to
indicate the date issued, name of the purchaser and the year and make of the
vehicle to which the permit is to be attached.
(‘89 Code, § 63.23)
   (E)   The fee for each off-street parking permit decal shall be $100 for
each full calendar year, provided that the fee shall be prorated on a monthly
basis to the nearest whole month when purchased after the first day of January
of any year. The fee shall be collected by the Clerk-Treasurer.
(‘89 Code, § 63.24) (Am. Ord. 65, passed 12-16-96; Am. Ord. passed - - ; Am.
Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
   (F)   The purchaser of a permit may not assign or transfer it to another
person.
(‘89 Code, § 63.25)
   (G)   The funds collected from the sale of the permits shall be allocated as
provided for in §
72.32.
(‘89 Code, § 63.26)
   (H)   No person shall park in any space designated as being restricted to
off-street parking permits without having the permit displayed on the vehicle
being parked, and violation of this division shall be considered to be a
restricted parking violation
(‘89 Code, § 63.28)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 72.35 HANDICAPPED PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall park a motor vehicle which does not have a valid
handicapped persons or disabled veteran’s placard or license plate in a parking
space reserved by sign and/or pavement paint for a handicapped person’s
vehicle.
   (B)   No person shall knowingly park in a reserved handicapped parking space
while displaying a placard or plate to which neither the person nor the
person’s passenger is entitled.
   (C)   No person shall display for use in a reserved handicapped parking
space a placard or special license plate that was not issued pursuant to the
laws of Indiana or the laws of another state.
   (D)   No person shall park in a handicapped parking space a vehicle that
displays a placard or special license plate entitling a person to park in a
reserved handicapped parking space unless that person is, at that time
handicapped, or in the process of transporting a handicapped person.
(‘89 Code, § 63.27)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 72.36 FINES.
   (A)   The following is the fine schedule for the various violations of this
chapter:
      (1)   For a two-hour violation, three-hour violation, meter violation or
restricted parking violation, or a “city permit only” violation, a fine of $15;
      (2)   For a no parking violation, alley parking violation, double parking
violation and yellow zone parking violation, a fine of $30;
      (3)   For a handicapped parking violation, fire hydrant parking
violation, fire zone parking violation and fire lane parking violation, a fine
of $75; and
      (4)   Any additional parking violations shall be subject to a fine of
$15.
   (B)   If a violation described in division (A)(1) or (2) occurs, the Police
and Fire Department has the full right and authority to have the vehicle towed
out of the restricted area. The owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for
all costs incurred as a result of having the vehicle towed. These costs
include, but are not limited to, towing services, storage and any damages to
the car arising as a result of the removal of the vehicle.
   (C)   All moneys received under this section shall be receipted into the
Parking Meter Fund.
   (D)   In the event that any fine as indicated under division (A)(1), (2),
(3), or (4) above are not paid within 14 days of the date of issuance, the fine
for the violation shall be doubled. In the event that a vehicle receives more
than one parking ticket on any given calendar day for violation of division (A)
above, the second parking ticket shall carry a fine in the amount of double the
amount of the first ticket and a third parking ticket issued on the same day at
the same location shall carry a fine in the amount of triple the amount of the
first ticket.
(‘89 Code, § 63.17) (Am. Ord. passed 6-27-94; Am. Ord. 2, passed 1-27-97; Am.
Ord. 26-2010, passed 8-23-10)
§ 72.37 VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION.
   (A)   Definition. For the purposes of this section, certain terms or words
used herein shall be given the following meanings:
      (1)   VEHICLE. Any device in, upon, or by which a person or property is,
or may be, transported or drawn upon a street or highway as defined in I.C. 9-
13-2-196.
      (2)   WHEEL LOCK DEVICE. Any device which shall be placed on a wheel of a
vehicle to immobilize the vehicle.
   (B)   Overdue parking fines.  The Council declares that in the event the
owner or operator of a vehicle owes overdue parking fines of $100 or more which
remain unpaid, in addition to any other penalties or fines permitted by law,
the Police Department or any other person or firm that the city may appoint or
hire, may immobilize the vehicle by use of a wheel lock device.
   (C)   Removal of wheel lock. Once a vehicle has been immobilized by the use
of the wheel lock device, the owner or operator of the vehicle can have the
wheel lock removed by paying to the Police Department a $75 service fee for
removal of the wheel lock device in addition to all fines imposed on all
overdue parking violations and/or violations of any other traffic laws of the
state or ordinances of the city.
   (D)   Impoundment. If, after the wheel lock device has been attached to the
vehicle, the owner or operator fails to pay all amounts due in division (C)
above within a 24-hour period (excluding weekends and holidays), the Police
Department may have the vehicle impounded until such time as the owner or
operator has paid the service fee plus all fines imposed on all overdue parking
violations and/or violations of any other traffic laws of the state or
ordinances of the city. The owner or operator of a vehicle that has been
impounded is liable for all charges for towing and storage of the vehicle.
   (E)   Liability for costs. The owner or operator of a vehicle found to be in
violation of this section shall be solely responsible and liable for all costs
incidental to the immobilization of the vehicle and its removal, storage and
disposal.
   (F)   City not liable for loss or damage. The city, its police officers,
agents, representatives and employees shall not be liable for the loss or
damage to any vehicle occurring during the installation or removal of the wheel
lock device and/or the removal, storage or disposition of said vehicle pursuant
to this section.
(Ord. 40-2008, passed 11-10-08)
SNOW EMERGENCY SYSTEM
§ 72.50 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PARKING LOT. That portion of land set aside for parking of automobiles or
other vehicles, which lots are owned and operated by the city.
   SIDEWALK. That portion of land set aside for pedestrian travel.
   STREET or HIGHWAY. The entire width between the boundary lines of any land
set aside for vehicular travel that is publicly maintained.
(‘89 code, § 93.01)
§ 72.51 VEHICLE REMOVAL.
   (A)   After a snowfall great enough to cause the center of the street or
highway to be plowed, all vehicles must be removed from that street or highway
until both sides of the street or highway are plowed from curb to curb or ditch
to ditch.
   (B)   In the event that a snowfall occurs which creates an emergency
endangering the smooth flow of emergency vehicles and other traffic, the City
Police Department may issue citations requiring the removal of the offending
vehicles from city streets or highways within 24 hours of the issuance of the
citation. During snowfalls the Police Department may designate the Street
Superintendent its representative with the authority to issue citations.
   (C)   The Police Department shall make every reasonable effort to contact
the owner or person exerting control over the vehicles within that time period.
If the cars or vehicles are not removed within the 24-hour period, the city
shall declare the cars or other vehicles to be a hazard to snow removal
operations and cause them to be removed and the owner or person exerting
control over the vehicle will then be responsible for the removal costs.
(‘89 Code, § 93.02) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
§ 72.52 CITY LOT.
   It shall be unlawful to park any kind of vehicle in a city owned parking lot
from 12:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. prevailing time. Any vehicle parked in a parking
lot during this time may be towed away and the owner or person exerting control
over the vehicle will be subject to removal costs. This section shall be
applicable at all times and is not restricted to snow emergencies only.
(‘89 Code, § 93.03) (Am. Ord. passed - -)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 72.53 OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC WAYS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to move snow, or cause snow to be
moved or piled on any sidewalk in the city.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to move snow or cause snow to be
moved from any driveway, parking lot, alley, sidewalk or other parcel of land
and deposit the same upon any street, highway or right-of-way of the city. The
City Street Department shall be exempt from the provisions of this section.
(‘89 Code, § 93.04)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 72.54 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Any person in violation of any provision of this subchapter shall,
upon conviction, be fined for each violation.
   (B)   When any police officer or agent of the city observes a violation of
this subchapter, he or she shall issue or request issuance of a citation
pursuant to this subchapter and shall comply with the notice provisions
contained herein. It shall not be a violation for the initial citation,
provided that the subject vehicle is removed within the 24-hour time limit.
(‘89 Code, § 93.05)
Penalty, see § 10.99
PARKING IN EAST GATE AND UNIVERSITY PROMENADE AREAS
§ 72.70 EAST GATE PARKING AREA.
   (A)   Eligibility for East Gate Area parking permit.
      (1)   Any property owner who resides within the area identified in
Exhibit "A", which is attached to Ord. 16, 2009 and incorporated herein by
reference, possessing a valid driver's license and automobile registration, may
apply to the Board of Works for a parking permit for one parking space in the
East Gate Parking Area, as defined by Exhibit "B" ("East Gate Parking Area"),
which is attached to Ord. 16, 2009 and incorporated herein by reference,
commencing August 14, 2009 and each succeeding year on August 14, except should
August 14 be a weekend or holiday recognized by the Council, than the next
business day shall apply. The submittal of a permit application by any such
resident does not guarantee the approval of the same.
      (2)   The owner of a multiple residential unit structure within the
designated East Gate Parking Area Parking Area that applies for multiple
parking permits for use by tenants must secure a permit application from each
recipient of a permit and maintain a record of each permit application.
Attached to Ord. 15-2018 as Exhibit A, and incorporated herein by reference, is
a form permit application. Upon request by the city, a copy of any such permit
application shall be provided to the city at no charge. Renewal of permits to
owners of a multiple residential unit structure within the designated East Gate
Parking Area need not be approved by the Board of Works.
      (3)   Except as provided in division (A)(2), no more than one permit can
be registered to the same address/unit at any given time.
   (B)   (1)   The City's Board of Public Works shall adopt a permit
application to be completed by all applicants. Such permit application shall
include a request for following information:
         (a)   The applicant's name and address;
         (b)   The year, make, and license plate number of the permitted
vehicle;
         (c)   A signed acknowledgment of the applicant that he/she resides at
the address given in the permit application;
         (d)   Certify that applicant has no outstanding unpaid city parking
violation and will timely pay any city parking violation while issued a permit;
         (e)   Payment of the appropriate registration fees which is non-
refundable; and
         (f)   A copy of the applicant's license and vehicle registration.
      (2)   Should any information on the permit application change while a
permit is active, the applicant shall provide written notice of such change to
the city.
   (C)   Parking permit hang tag required.
      (1)   The tag shall be placed on the vehicle's rearview minor at all
times when a vehicle is parked in either the East Gate Parking Area Parking
Area and be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Nothing in this provision
shall prohibit the city, acting through the Board of Works, from reverting back
to the use of parking decals.
      (2)   All administrative functions relating to the issuance of permits
shall be handled by the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (3)   Tags shall be designated separately for the East Gate Parking Area
and University Promenade Parking Area. Tags for one area shall not authorize
parking in another area.
      (4)   The fee for an annual tag shall be $250. There shall not be any
administrative fees or renewal fees. The replacement fee for a lost tag shall
be $100 if replacement tags are available. No replacement tags shall be issued
prior to December 1.
   (D)   Expiration/renewal of permits.
      (1)   All permits shall expire on July 31 of each year.
      (2)   Any resident or owner possessing a valid parking permit shall have
the opportunity to submit a renewal application starting July 20. Renewals
shall take precedent over new applications.
   (E)   Fees.
      (1)   An initial administrative fee of $25 and an annual permit fee of
$75 shall be paid upon issuance of a new permit.
      (2)   An annual permit renewal fee of $75 shall be paid thereafter for
those permits which are renewed.
      (3)   A replacement decal fee of $25 shall be collected for a new decal.
   (F)   Issuance and revocation of permits.
      (1)   The permit application for an East Gate Area parking permit shall
be submitted to the Board of Public Works. The Board of Public Works shall
approve or disapprove the application, subject to the provisions of this
section and the number of permits available. Should the number of permit
applications exceed the number of unissued permits, the Board of Works shall
establish a random assignment or some other equitable process to assign
permits.
      (2)   The City's Board of Public Works & Safety shall have the authority
to revoke any parking permit upon a finding of any violation of this section,
and to order the revocation of the parking permit and forfeiture of all fees
paid.
   (G)   Regulations for East Gate Area parking permit holders.
      (1)   Permits shall be restricted to one vehicle;
      (2)   Permits shall be valid until July 31 of each year;
      (3)   Parking spaces shall be used for passenger vehicles only; and
      (4)   Permits shall not be subleased or rented.
   (H)   Disposition of revenue. All funds derived from the granting of permits
shall be placed in the Parking Meter Fund.
   (I)   Violations. Fees for violations of this subchapter follow the schedule
provided in Ordinance 26-2010, as amended and codified in §
72.36 of the City Code. In addition to the foregoing, if a violation of this
section occurs, the City of Valparaiso Police Department and/or its designee
shall have the full right and authority to have the violating vehicle towed.
The owner of the vehicle shall be solely responsible for all costs incurred as
a result of having the vehicle towed.
(Ord. 16, 2009, passed 7-27-09; Am. Ord. 15-2018, passed 8-27-18; Am. Ord. 17-
2021, passed 7-26-21)
§ 72.71 UNIVERSITY PROMENADE PARKING AREA.
   (A)   Eligibility for University Promenade Area parking permit.
      (1)   Any property owner who resides within the area identified in
Exhibit "A", which is attached to Ord. 12-2015 and incorporated herein by
reference, possessing a valid driver's license and automobile registration, may
apply to the Board of Public Works and Safety of the City of Valparaiso,
Indiana ("Board of Works"), for a parking permit for one parking space in the
University Promenade Parking Area, as depicted by Exhibit "B" ("University
Promenande Parking Area"), which is attached to Ord. 12-2015 and incorporated
herein by reference, commencing June 1, 2015 and each succeeding year on August
1, except should August 1 be a weekend or holiday recognized by the Common
Council, then the next business day shall apply. The submittal of a permit
application by such residence does not guarantee the approval of same.
      (2)   The owner of a multiple residential unit structure within the
designated University Promenade Parking Area Parking Area that applies for
multiple parking permits for use by tenants must secure a permit application
from each recipient of a permit and maintain a record of each permit
application. Attached to Ord. 15-2018 as Exhibit A, and incorporated herein by
reference, is a form permit application. Upon request by the city, a copy of
any such permit application shall be provided to the city at no charge. Renewal
of permits to owners of a multiple residential unit structure within the
designated University Promenade Parking Area need not be approved by the Board
of Works.
      (3)   Except as provided in division (A)(2), no more than one permit can
be registered to the same address/unit at any given time.
   (B)   Permit application.
      (1)   The Board of Works shall adopt a permit application to be completed
by all applicants. Such permit application shall include a request for the
following information:
         (a)   The applicant's name and address;
         (b)   The year, make and license plate number of the permitted
vehicle;
         (c)   A signed acknowledgement of the applicant that he/she resides at
the address given in the permit application;
         (d)   Certify that applicant has no outstanding unpaid city parking
violations and will timely pay any city parking violation while issued a
permit;
         (e)   Payment of the appropriate registration fees which is non-
refundable; and
         (f)   C copy of the applicant's vehicle registration.
      (2)   Should any information on the permit application change while a
permit is active, the applicant shall provide written notice of such change to
the city.
   (C)   Parking permit hang tag required.
      (1)   The tag shall be placed on the vehicle's rearview minor at all
times when a vehicle is parked in either the University Promenade Parking Area
and be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Nothing in this provision
shall prohibit the city, acting through the Board of Works, from reverting back
to the use of parking decals.
      (2)   All administrative functions relating to the issuance of permits
shall be handled by the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (3)   Tags shall be designated separately for the East Gate Parking Area
and University Promenade Parking Area. Tags for one area shall not authorize
parking in another area.
      (4)   The fee for an annual Tag shall be $250. There shall not be any
administrative fees or renewal fees. The replacement fee for a lost tag shall
be $100 if replacement tags are avai lable. No replacement tags shall be issued
prior to December 1.
   (D)   Expiration/renewal of permits.
      (1)   All permits shall expire on July 31 of each year.
      (2)   Any resident or owner possessing a valid parking permit shall have
the opportunity to submit a renewal application starting July 20. Renewals
shall take precedent over new applications.
   (E)   Fees.
      (1)   An initial administrative fee of $25 and an annual permit fee of
$200 shall be paid upon issuance of a new permit.
      (2)   An annual permit renewal fee of $200 thereafter for those permits
which are renewed.
      (3)   A replacement decal fee of $25 shall be collected for a new decal.
      (4)   The Board of Works shall have the authority to adjust all fees
under this section.
   (F)   Issuance and revocation of permits.
      (1)   The permit application for a University Promenade Area parking
permit shall be submitted to the Board of Public Works and Safety. The Board of
Public Works and Safety shall approve or disapprove the application, subject to
the provisions of this section and the number of permits available. Should the
number of permit applications exceed the number of unissued permits, the Board
of Public Works and Safety shall establish a random assignment or some other
equitable process to assign permits.
      (2)   The City's Board of Public Works and Safety shall have the
authority to revoke any parking permit upon a finding of any violation of this
section, and to order the revocation of the parking permit and forfeiture of
all fees paid.
   (G)   Regulations for University Promenade Area parking permit holders/
permit parking hours. The following regulations shall apply to all University
Promenade Area parking permit holders:
      (1)   Permits shall be registered to one vehicle;
      (2)   Permits shall be valid until July 31 of each year;
      (3)   Parking spaces shall be used for passenger vehicles only; and
      (4)   Permits shall not be subleased or rented.
   (H)   Disposition of revenue. All funds derived from the granting of permits
shall be placed in the Parking Meter Fund.
   (I)   Violations. Fees for violations of this subchapter follow the schedule
provided in Ordinance 26-2010, as amended and codified in §
72.36 of the City Code. In addition to the foregoing, if a violation of this
section occurs, the City of Valparaiso Police Department and/or its designee
shall have the full right and authority to have the violating vehicle towed.
The owner of the vehicle shall be solely responsible for all costs incurred as
a result of having the vehicle
   (J)   Explanation of dates. As referenced in this section, the City Council
adopted Ordinance 16-2009 to address parking congestion near the Uptown
Apartment complex. Recognizing that most parking permits would be used by
apartment residents, who are students at Valparaiso University, the yearly
terms of the permits were August 14 through July 31 of the first year, and
August 1 through July 31 of each succeeding year. The intent of this section is
to follow the same schedule. As such, in the first year, permits will be valid
June 1, 2015 through July 31, 2016. In subsequent years, permits will be valid
August 1 through July 31 of the following year.
   (K)   Joint enforcement by Valparaiso University. As of the adoption of this
section, there have been ongoing discussions with Valparaiso University
concerning the joint enforcement of this section by authorized Valparaiso
University employees/representatives. Such discussions may be memorialized by a
Memorandum of Understanding entered between the City's Board of Public Works
and Safety and Valparaiso University. Such Memorandum of Understanding, as
amended, is incorporated by reference into this section and will outline the
process of joint enforcement by Valparaiso University.
(Ord. 12-2015, passed 6-22-15; Am. Ord. 15-2018, passed 8-27-18; Am. Ord. 17-
2021, passed 7-26-21)

§ 90.01 FINDING.
   The City Council finds that abandoned vehicles are a public nuisance and a
safety and health hazard.
(‘89 Code, § 76.01)
§ 90.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED VEHICLE.
      (1)   A vehicle located on public property illegally;
      (2)   A vehicle left on public property continuously without being moved
for three days;
      (3)   A vehicle located on public property in such a manner as to
constitute a hazard or obstruction to the movement of pedestrian or vehicle
traffic on a public right-of-way;
      (4)   A vehicle that has remained on the private property without the
consent of the owner or person in control of that property for more than 48
hours;
      (5)   A vehicle from which there has been removed the engine,
transmission or differential, or that is otherwise partially dismantled or
inoperable and left on public property;
      (6)   A vehicle that has been removed by a towing service or a public
agency upon request of an officer enforcing a statute or ordinance, if the
vehicle, once impounded, is not claimed or redeemed by the owner or his or her
agent within 15 days of its removal; and/or
      (7)   A vehicle that is six or more model years old and mechanically
inoperable, and is left on private property continuously in a location visible
from the public property for more than 30 days.
   AUTOMOBILE SCRAPYARD. A business organized for the purpose of scrap metal
processing, automobile wrecking or operating a junkyard.
   BUREAU.  The Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
   FISCAL BODY. The City Council.
   OFFICER.
      (1)   A regular member of the State Police;
      (2)   A regular member of a city or town police department;
      (3)   A regular member of the County Police Department; or
      (4)   An individual of an agency designated by ordinance of the fiscal
body.
   OWNER. The last known record titleholder of a vehicle according to the
records of the Bureau under state law.
   PARTS. All components of a vehicle that, as assembled, do not constitute a
complete vehicle.
   PERSON. An individual, firm, corporation, association, fiduciary or
governmental entity.
   PRIVATE PROPERTY. All property other than public property.
   PUBLIC AGENCY. The bureau or local agency given the responsibility by
statute or ordinance for removal, storage and disposal of abandoned vehicles.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY. A public right-of-way, street, highway, alley, park or
other state, county or municipal property.
   TOWING SERVICE. A business that engages in moving or removing disabled
vehicles and, once removed, to store or impound vehicles.
   VEHICLE. An automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semitrailer, tractor,
bus, school bus, recreational vehicle or motorized bicycle.
(‘89 Code, § 76.02)
§ 90.03 LIABILITY OF OWNER.
   (A)   The owner of an abandoned vehicle is responsible for the abandonment
and is liable for all of the costs incidental to the removal, storage and
disposal of the vehicle or the parts.
   (B)   When an officer discovers a vehicle in the possession of a person
other than the owner and the person cannot establish his or her right to the
possession of that vehicle, the vehicle shall be taken to and stored in a
suitable place. The Bureau shall be notified within 72 hours of the location
and description of the vehicle.
   (C)   If the owner of the vehicle cannot be determined, the Bureau shall
declare the vehicle abandoned and provide for its disposal in accordance with
this chapter.
   (D)   If the properly identified owner or lienholder appears at the site of
storage before disposal of the vehicle or parts and pays all proper costs
incurred against it at that time, then the vehicle or parts shall be released.
A copy of the release of all vehicles or parts shall be sent to the Bureau. The
release must contain the owner or lienholder’s signature, name, address,
vehicle or parts description, costs and date of release.
   (E)   If the vehicle is not released to the owner or lienholder, the Bureau
shall declare the vehicle abandoned and provide for disposal in accordance with
this chapter.
(‘89 Code, § 76.03)
§ 90.04 NOTICE TAGS.
   (A)   An officer who finds a vehicle or parts believed to be abandoned shall
attach in a prominent place a notice tag containing the following information:
      (1)   The date, time, officer’s name, public agency and address and
telephone number to contact for information;
      (2)   The vehicle or parts are considered abandoned;
      (3)   The vehicle or parts will be removed after 72 hours;
      (4)   The owner will be held responsible for all costs incidental to the
removal, storage and disposal, and if not paid the owner’s registration
privileges will be suspended on that car; and
      (5)   The owner may avoid costs by removal of the vehicle or parts within
72 hours.
   (B)   If the tagged vehicle or parts are not removed within that 72-hour
period, the officer shall prepare a written abandoned vehicle report of the
vehicle or parts including information on the condition, missing parts, and
other facts that might substantiate that the market value is less than $100.
   (C)   If, in the opinion of the officer, the market value of the abandoned
vehicle or parts is less than $100, the officer shall immediately dispose of
the vehicle to an automobile scrapyard. A copy of the abandoned vehicle report
and photographs relating to the abandoned vehicle shall be forwarded to the
Bureau. The public agency disposing of the vehicle shall retain the original
records and photographs for at least two years.
   (D)   If, in the opinion of the officer, the market value of the abandoned
vehicle or parts is $100 or more, the officer, before placing a notice tag on
the vehicle or parts, shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain the owner or
person who may be in control of the vehicle or parts. After 72 hours, the
officer shall require the vehicle or parts to be towed to a storage area.
(‘89 Code, § 76.05)
§ 90.05 ABANDONED VEHICLE REPORT.
   Within 72 hours after removal of an abandoned vehicle to a storage area
under §
90.04, the public agency shall prepare and forward to the Bureau an abandoned
vehicle report containing a description of the vehicle including the make,
model, engine number, if any, identification number and the number of the
license plate, and request that the Bureau advise the public agency of the name
and most recent mailing address of the owner and any lienholder.
(‘89 Code, § 76.06)
§ 90.06 DISPOSITION AND SALE OF STORED VEHICLES.
   If the vehicle or parts are in such a condition that vehicle identification
numbers or other means of identification are not available to determine the
owner or lienholder, the vehicle may be disposed of without notice.
(‘89 Code, § 76.07)
§ 90.07 BILL OF SALE; TITLE; FEE.
   The purchaser shall be furnished a bill of sale for each abandoned vehicle
sold by the public agency. The fee for the bill of sale is $6. Should the
purchaser wish to obtain a title for the vehicle acquired, he or she shall
present evidence from a law enforcement agency that the vehicle is roadworthy
and pay the appropriate title fee.
(‘89 Code, § 76.08)
§ 90.08 OPTIONS FOR REMOVAL.
   In order to facilitate the removal of abandoned vehicles or parts, the
public agency may employ personnel and acquire equipment, property and
facilities, and enter into towing contracts as necessary for the purpose of
removal, storage and disposition of abandoned vehicles and parts. The fiscal
body may establish, by ordinance, procedures to accomplish the purposes of this
section.
(‘89 Code, § 76.09)
§ 90.09 VEHICLES LEFT ON PRIVATE PROPERTY; COMPLAINTS.
   Upon complaint of a private property owner or person in control of the
property that a vehicle has been left on the property for 48 hours or more
without the consent of the owner or person in control, an officer shall follow
the procedures set forth in §
90.04.
(‘89 Code, § 76.10)
§ 90.10 LIABILITY FOR LOSS OR DAMAGE TO VEHICLES DURING REMOVAL, STORAGE OR
DISPOSITION.
   Neither the owner, lessee or occupant of the property from which an
abandoned vehicle or parts are removed nor a public agency, officer, towing
service or automobile scrapyard is liable for loss or damage to the vehicle or
parts occurring during its removal, storage or disposition.
(‘89 Code, § 76.11)
§ 90.11 PROCEEDS OF SALE CREDITED AGAINST COSTS.
   The proceeds of sale of an abandoned vehicle or parts shall be credited
against all costs incident to the removal, storage, and disposal of the
vehicle.
(‘89 Code, § 76.12)
§ 90.12 ABANDONED VEHICLE ACCOUNT.
   All proceeds from the sale of abandoned vehicles or parts that are sold by
local units, including charges for bills of sale, and all monies received from
owners or lienholders for the cost of removal or storage of vehicles shall be
deposited with the City Clerk-Treasurer and placed by him or her in the
Abandoned Vehicle Account. All costs incurred by a public agency in
administering this chapter shall be paid from the Abandoned Vehicle Account.
The fiscal body shall annually appropriate sufficient monies to that account
for the purposes of this chapter. All monies remaining in the account at the
end of each year remain in the account and do not revert to the General Fund.
(‘89 Code, § 76.13)
§ 90.13 EXEMPT VEHICLES.
   This chapter does not apply to:
   (A)   A vehicle in operable condition specifically adapted or constructed
for operation on privately owned raceways;
   (B)   A vehicle stored as the property of a member of the armed forces of
the United States who is on active duty assignment;
   (C)   A vehicle located on a vehicle sale lot or at a commercial vehicle
servicing facility;
   (D)   A vehicle located upon property licensed or zoned as an automobile
scrapyard; or
   (E)   A vehicle registered and licensed under I.C. 9-13-2-3 as an antique
vehicle.
(‘89 Code, § 76.14)
